data.text:
So..we‚Äôve had a few extra posts last month, due to the launch of Vice‚Äôs Creators Project (tomorrow), but I feel as though I missed my actual end of the month post as a result!!

On the box

Last month I had a reader‚Äôs review of GLEE published in The Independent‚Äôs Arts/Books section, which you can find amongst the thoughts of other readers here.

Besides that, I‚Äôm not watching a lot of TV‚Ä¶although the occasional episode of Victoria Coren‚Äôs Only Connect on BBC 4 is like Actimel for the soul. I especially like the fact that despite team names like ‚ÄúRugby Boys‚Äù and ‚ÄúHistory Boys‚Äù, they‚Äôre all just neeks who can solve complex puzzles which make 3am Quizcall on Channel 5 look like playschool. Especially love the (very rare) occasions when I get something right.

The current series of Big Brother is also providing good entertainment whenever I flick onto it, and Emmerdale lookylikey Nathan‚Äôs monobrow has luckily been evicted. Desperate Housewives has just finished its sensational sixth season, which saw a triptych of psychos, copious amounts of flashbacks and *tear* Mike and Susan leaving Wisteria Lane. Silver fox Paul Young (Duck from Mad Men ‚Äì portrayed by Mark Moses) is back on the scene, however. I‚Äôm rewatching some of the latter at the moment, so the next season of Housewives could be very confusing for me indeed, having become accustomed to seeing Mr Moses in 60s mode.

Girl‚Äôs just wanna have fun (and not much else)

WARNING: MAY CONTAIN SATC2 SPOILERS

Late as I am, SATC2 was a ton of fun.

I wish I‚Äôd seen it earlier. Casual racism, gay stereotyping, marital cliches and Samantha‚Äôs (Kim Cattrall) grossness aside, it was a great laugh. Moreover, SJP was on form as Carrie Bradshaw (or Preston) and the Abu Dhabi scenes were beautiful, despite being filmed 4000 miles away in Morrocco (ironically, due to the same Islamic strictness of the UAE which the film constantly lampoons). The plot looses its way more than a few times, but is saved by some genuine laughs courtesy of cameos from Liza Minnelli as herself, performing at said gay stereotypes wedding, and Miley Cyrus, who turns up at a premiere in the same ‚Äúyoung‚Äù frock as Samantha. Said dress is rather Littlewoods for the stars to be wearing, but I‚Äôm sure it was a designer number. There is tons of product placement in the film, as one would expect, but which is all the more distracting given the ‚Äúexotic‚Äù setting. The Arabic Pringles aren‚Äôt particuarly rare, either, SJP ‚Äì we‚Äôve been buying them in the pound shop forever in the real world. Anyways, I digress: SATC2 is a cheap laugh rather than a well-plotted and wholesome one. There is some fleeting realism via Charlotte‚Äôs insecurities (with the gorgeous Alice Eve as her Gaelic nanny Erin, who wouldn‚Äôt be worried?) but this is quickly usurped by stupidity, as director Michael Patrick King decides to go kamikaze, peppering the flick with millions of unneccessary shots of Eve‚Äôs bra-less nipples which probably contributed towards the film‚Äôs poor reception. The outcome of the lazy storytelling is that overSexed and The City is a whopping three hours long. By the end, I felt as though I‚Äôd been beaten over the head with a Complete Seasons 1-6 boxset. Not only was the film overly drawn out, it felt a million miles away from the innovation which the original SATC had. Age-wise the ‚Äúgirls‚Äù have outgrown the format, but I fear that perhaps we‚Äôve all tired of their antics and nineties semantics, too.

At least Cougar Town kind of had a noughties ‚Äúmenopause-chic‚Äù, a Demi and Ashton vibe‚Ä¶Sex and The City 2 is good fun, but it does feel dated.When Charlotte (Kristin Davis) cries about her ruined ‚Äúvintage Valentino‚Äù she is pretty much a cariacture of herself.

So, what can we take away from this Emirates-set escapade? Don‚Äôt cheat on your husband, perhaps? Even that doesn‚Äôt quite follow, with Carrie and Big making good of their relationship, even after the former kisses an ex-love in aforesaid foreign climes. In conclusion, SATC2 is a slice of the big apple without all the chewy bits (storytelling, drama, genuine adventure). The racebending here wasn‚Äôt as awful as Prince of Persia (Gyllenhaal as an arab?), but boy, must Omid Djalili and Raza Jaffrey be having some serious cash issues right now.

More acerbic words from the rainy environs of London coming up soon, when I hit Truck festival and Underage with Artrocker, and pump some PR into the blog with brand, brand, spanking new content.

Dear my faithfuls‚Ä¶I‚Äôd give you all my last Rolo if I could. But I can‚Äôt due to the laws of physics and such.

This month has been seriously busy for me due to AS Levels. Such a cop-out, but as I‚Äôm seriously dedicated to high quality content I feel that rather than a coherent blog I‚Äôll just roll out links to 5 cool things I‚Äôm enjoying right now and apologise profusely. Please follow me on twitter (@hannahjdavies) and I‚Äôll spew more nonsense there.

1.MIA ROSE is a chanteuse and a bit of a flanteuse when she sings sitting on her bed but‚Ä¶

She‚Äôs really beautiful (think Glee‚Äôs Rachel meets Norah Jones meets Penelope Cruz) and although she‚Äôs been around a few years, (and endured more than a few suspcions over her seemingly huge Youtube following) this songstress never fails to make me smile. File her covers and Gibson-playing between Colbie Caillat and Sheryl Crow, even though she has been managed by Tommy Mottolla (Mariah‚Äôs ex).

And she wears quite a few hats. Something which kinda adds to her girl-next-door vibe.

2. Harry Hill‚Äôs paintings

They‚Äôre almost as hilarious than his TV show, and Harry Hill‚Äôs paintings provoke more of a smile than a Burp ‚Äì as seen in this week‚Äôs Observer. I especially like Parker-Bowles Windsor (below) the love child of Camilla and Charles who is a decidedly ominous creamy spacehopper with more of a resembelence to Robin Williams in Flubber. I digress ‚Äì a symbol, perhaps, of our strange relationship with the couple and (pathetically) undying love for Princess Diana.

3. Money

Not in note-form, although you can make any cheques payable to me. Nope, I‚Äôm talking about the 2-part adaptation of Martin Amis‚Äô novel with Vincent Kartheiser (Mad Men) and Nick Frost (Hot Fuzz) which recently graced our screens on BBC2. Reeeaaaalllly good (a little subjective as I‚Äôm a Martin Amis fan) but this was a really fun bit of 80s which should sit alongside the Rayban revival, John Hughes films being shown late at night and Vice Magazine‚Äôs Bret Easton Ellis interview this month.

Here‚Äôs a useless picture of Vince just to illustrate how symmetrical his face is. I think he might use Carmex, too. The guy who over-straightens his hair on Junior Apprentice could also take a few tips from Karthy‚Äôs bouncy straight locks which are statically mussed up a little on top as to appear nonchalant, but calmed with serum. I can smell Frederic Fekkai through my computer.

4. Twitterings

After over a year leaving tiny nuggets of mundanity and picking up quickly aggregated news and cynical musings and (possibly made-up) gossip from the twitterati, I don‚Äôt want to leave. It‚Äôs too fun, especially when real-life augments itself into Twitter via pictures, mentions and locations (becoming a mayor of Oxford St McDonalds on FourSquare is my next goal).

I even recorded a voiceover for reviews site The 405 (server isn‚Äôt working so here is the link: http://thefourohfive.com) after chatting on Twitter, and the manager of Cha Cha sent me this video after finding me on there:

Admittedly its too inoffensive, slick and overpolished for my liking, and lacks personality, but it is a cute video and i really do respond to everything which is emailed to me.

5. Festival essentials

Summer‚Äôs almost here, and I really want a Hunter festival survival pack (available from Office) ‚Äì tons of good stuff packed into a one litre flask with Hunter logo in the classic mossy green colour, which is actually just known as Green. I. Need. This.

Urban Outfitters ‚ÄòContrast Trim Satchel‚Äô is probably too shallow to fit that massive bottle into, but I like it anyways due to its Americana feel and oversized clasp. I‚Äôm no Mariella Tandy but yum.

If money were no object I‚Äôd probably be stuffing everything into one of these stunning pouches courtesy of Felder Felder at Browns, which perfectly marry my ambition to be part of some outlaw motorcycling club in Arkansas with my (pipe) dream of designing a haute couture collection based on dirt and leather and saloon doors. Enough space or keys, plasters and a bit of cash although unfortunately ¬£190. If Matalan are reading this, please make a copy for ¬£4.

Yours

Its April/May. The showers are coming down on my window like sweat on a pubescent kid‚Äôs spotty forehead in a tennis lesson (not speaking from experience here) and exams are impending BUT I still reserve a little time for such art forms as interviewing cool creatives like the guys from ad agency C.R.A.P !! Below you can see me prodding the collective intellect of Scottish Ad Men Chris Rush & Andy Peel.

FIRST UP: Top tips for advertising and some ‚Äúrandom words‚Äù from C.R.A.P.

Subjectively, they‚Äôre the new Saatchi & Saatchi. I know someone will execute me for that. To save you from CSI-type measures, his name will be Charles Saatchi and he will be in the conservatory with the lead pipe.

HJD: Due to the popularity of Mad Men, which has just finished its oh-so-stylish third series, do you guys think that the ad world is getting a makeover? And, of course, what‚Äôs the most glamourous part of your day job?

AP: [its] between people spending money on our ideas and going on shoots. Traveling the world(ish) and meeting celebs is pretty good, and you can live in the pub so long as you‚Äôve got some awesome work to show for it when you stagger out.

CR: ^What? *reality check Peely* maybe getting free drinks on expenses? We can go anywhere to do ‚Äòwork‚Äô and not pay a thing when we‚Äôre there. Anywhere can be the office‚Ä¶ till I have to direct some art at least.

HJD: Sterling Cooper Draper Pryce (Mad Men) vs CRAP (you). Whats in a name, and do you honestly think your, well, crap? Do clients call you ‚Äòcrap‚Äô or C.R.A.P? Or is it like M*A*S*H where the periods are ignored? Help.

AP: to start with, the name was everything. we were crap. We took the piss out ourselves because of people didn‚Äôt like our work, we told them ‚Äúwhat did you expect from crap?‚Äù CRAP got us noticed and remembered. It works, but because he‚Äôs CR and I‚Äôm AP. If i was John and CR was Bob, being crap wouldn‚Äôt have a purpose. And it‚Äôs always crap, except my dad hates it, so to him we‚Äôre c.r.a.p.

CR: Clients don‚Äôt really know us. For the most part only the account handlers deal with them, there are exceptions of course. cr.ap is memorable. It just works for that. When doing crits (HJD: book crits are visits to ad agencies to try and get work by showing a portfolio) we‚Äôd start out by telling them we are crap ‚Äì its on the cover of the front page of the portfolio ‚Äì then anything they see from then on might not be crap. We‚Äôre getting better, not entirely crap anymore but always cr.ap

HJD: At least your not Chris Underwood and Nathan Thomas, I here that their agency didnt go down too well. Jokes aside, how did you guys get into the business and what advise would you give to someone of about my age (17) who is thinking of getting into the PR or mad ad world?

AP: I didn‚Äôt have a clue. I did an ad course, after year one I teamed up with Chris and then started getting book crits and placements ever since. Network, work hard and being nice go a long way. Plus being good at it helps. Find a coach/mentor that‚Äôll help is a bonus. See our Facebook group for more.

CR: Have fun. Meet people -agency people all ‚Äòhave been there once‚Äô and most will give you good advice on how to get into the industry. There‚Äôs not one set method that works, as a creative it relies a lot on timing, luck and of course you being willing to put the graft in. And be polite. Everyone knows everyone in this industry, piss one off and the rest can hear about it‚Ä¶

We got here by not being perfect. We made a lot of mistakes and did a lot of bad ads. It‚Äôs how you learn. Literally. Just practice. Meeting people who can push you in the right direction helps and don‚Äôt rely on just one person‚Äôs opinion because it is just that: an opinion. Always try and get several people looking at your work, then you can take a consensus from that.

AP: Sound advice Mr Rush.

HJD: Sound advice indeed. I‚Äôm curious as to what has been your favourite project to date and why? (my personal fave is the Jaffalympics above)

AP: A toss up between our first TV shoot for the Scottish News of the World and our pitch win for Scotrail which will break nationally (in Scotland) in the summer. (HJD: Scotrail is the Scottish railway if you hadn‚Äôt guessed).

CR: What AP said plus the Smoking campaign for Northern Ireland. It was effective and got a lot of good response.

AP: It‚Äôs because you got to fly to Belfast you jammie git. It looked pretty good though, *pats head*.

HJD: ‚ÄúCRAP is one guy drawing and one guy writing‚Äù ‚Äì discuss

AP: One Photoshops, one waffles, but it works. I don‚Äôt think we‚Äôve been blown our cover yet.

CR: I can‚Äôt spell, he can.

HJD: Would you ever consider more government propaganda‚Ä¶I mean, information campaigns‚Ä¶like your work for the NHS?

AP: of course, we worked with the Scottish and Northern Ireland Governments before. Sexual health, drinking and smoking. So long as it‚Äôs for a good cause we‚Äôll sell our souls.

CR: They aren‚Äôt propaganda, there‚Äôs a difference between telling someone they must quit smoking and suggesting they do. We don‚Äôt really ‚Äòconsider‚Äô whether we do a brief or not anyway. It‚Äôs a job, it pays the company‚Äôs bills so it has to be done. We‚Äôd never get a product that it is wrong to advertise because they aren‚Äôt allowed to be advertised. We do of course get some briefs we‚Äôd rather not have‚Ä¶like a girls beauty brief thats on my desk right now.

AP: that‚Äôs true. A brainstorm with 6 women is a scary moment. Especially when you can‚Äôt get a word in edgeways over the ‚Äúisn‚Äôt he just gorgeous‚Äù or ‚Äúeugh, fat thighs‚Äù.

Mr A.I.D.S: one of CR.AP‚Äôs NHS initiatives simplifies serious illness for dramatic effect.

HJD: Better than working on those disgusting ads where those women discuss diarrhoea over lunch. Finally, who would be your dream client and why? For example, if I had any idea about the ad world whatsoever I would love to make an advert where a car is created out of cake..ohh thats been done‚Ä¶

AP: Chris and John at Fallon (who made the Skoda cake ad) gave us our first crit and placement. I‚Äôd love to work on Sony, Nike or Coke. But something closer to home would be good.

CR: A one that just allows creativity to shine through instead of worrying about the size of a frigging logo. It‚Äôs amazing the difference between an original idea and the work which the general public end up seeing. 9/10 its a watered down version that isn‚Äôt anywhere near as good. So not a specific client, just one that wants to be creative and bold.

AP: I think our portfolio has a few of those in‚Ä¶

HJD: Thanks guys, all the best‚Ä¶Can‚Äôt wait to see if these guys do become the Real Life ‚ÄòMad Men‚Äô (which, by the way, I really don‚Äôt advise)

BEST OF THE REST

Oh, and some of their superb offerings make it into the paper VICE magazine. My mateys The Ruskins come from Isleworth (not too far from me) and I can‚Äôt believe they‚Äôre still unsigned. Not for long I hope/bet. Here‚Äôs their latest offering, Old Isleworth‚Ä¶the video features Elliott Tittensor (Shameless) and Kaya ‚ÄúEffy‚Äù Scodelario.

Its a cracker.

ALSO LOVING: OK GO, Lou Reed, N Sync, Amy Studt (yes I know), Sparks, Interpol (back on form), Julian Plenti‚Ä¶

And this:

Yes, that is Corbin Bleu‚Äôs Deal With It you can hear there‚Ä¶turns out that a whiley Jay Sean penned the song for the Afroed teen and sold the music to Korean superstars Shinee too. Clever move. Cleverer than that smug ‚Äòblazer dance‚Äô in the Down video, anyway‚Ä¶

Yours critically,

‚Ä¶And here you were thinking I was overaxaggerating. I might not have been raised by animals to sing Disney songs this

month, BUT I did have a great month regardless. My new nickname is Mowgli ‚Äì given by a dear friend but disliked nonetheless. Why can‚Äôt a girl be a bit free with her massive curly hair and poor make-up regime, without being compared to a fictional eunuch, eh?

Anyhow, I digress: this month I appeared on the popular BBC programme Question Time, which was a laugh-and-a-half

‚Ä¶okay, it was a serious show featuring political prowess BUT it was as close to TV fame as I‚Äôm gonna get now that Jungle Run is a distant memory. I always wanted a bike/scooter/Gameboy colour.

Question Time was a great experience, and one that I won‚Äôt forget in a hurry despite not getting my massive gob on TV. And I met David Dimbleby (legend) who listened to my views on the control of policing despite being on his way off to the pub üôÇ

Here‚Äôs a humorous picture of me to lighten the mood of this thoroughly disjointed entry:

Shall I go blonde? Hmmm‚Ä¶either way, dressing as Alice In Wonderland for my friend Emily‚Äôs birthday party (British themed) was a true eye-opener to the great hair debate. Suddenly I was crazily energetic and ca refree‚Ä¶no longer a sensible, coy brunette‚Ä¶

Actually, I think I look a bit like Dolly Parton myself‚Ä¶

I feel slightly lazy today due to flu (not of the swine variety, hopefully), so here‚Äôs something I cooked up earlier, a review of Mad Men, a show which I love so dearly. It‚Äôs in a classy font, and not-so-subtly followed by pictures of this month‚Äôs ‚ÄòOld Man Crush‚Äô, Jon Hamm. It‚Äôs a fantastic show ‚Äì BBC4, 10pm, Tuesdays are the place to be for the vintage stuff (which unfortunately has to end next week as the magnificent 2nd season draws to a close)‚Ä¶

Truly MADly Deeply

Mutually Assured Delight has swept over my TV screen, as I‚Äôve prepared to stage some wholly pretentious conversations about advertising, glamour and aestheticism. Yes, I‚Äôve been watching Mad Men for all of twelve weeks, and I‚Äôm gripped.

Dapper men (such as the gorgeous protagonist Don Draper, played by Jon Hamm), Brycreemed to the max and trying it on with their secretaries, their clients‚Äô wives or whoever happens to be nearest to the Xerox: check. The underappreciated wives; neglected whilst their husbands devise great copy for Clearasil, or ‚Äòspend a little time‚Äô with the aforementioned floozies: check. The deficient 2.4 children, putting the nuclear into nuclear family, making cocktails for mummy and daddy, and being berated in a terrific style for asking such uncouth classics as ‚Äúare we rich?‚Äù Check.

Mad Men has stolen my Tuesday nights and transported them into a bourgeoisie world, which smells of smoke and sex and classy instrumentals. It honestly looks like a real 1980s made-for-tv-movie set in the 50s; such is the realism, the costumery and the expert camerawork. Mad Men is the truth behind both the tension and allure of the office, and I would give anything to be part of a fantasy which includes Elnett in a starring role.

‚Äî

‚Ä¶sang Lily Allen back in December when she appeared with other ‚Äòcelebs‚Äô to see the new year in with Jools Holland. Was she singing about a certain ‚ÄòLady‚Äô, or simply reciting a song chosen by her mangagement, is the baffling question which I would now love to disect, whether or not you actually care üôÇ

A TALE OF TWO CITIES (AND THEIR DAHLINGS):

In the blue c orner, LDN‚Äôs Tesco-Alfresco Finest, Lily Allen‚Ä¶

The obligatory fairytale: Once upon a time, an unconvincing indie ‚Äògrimesterrrrr‚Äô turned into an unconvincing LA dahling. First propelled to fame by daddy dearest after enjoying a supposedly awful unbringing, said ‚Äògrimesterrrrr‚Äô turned being a brat into her career.

Likes to‚Ä¶ : Cringeworthily cry about how fat, ugly and talentless she is via MySpace like a 13 year old emo, cuss down other female celebrities, play dress up at boutiques, complain about ‚Äòold men‚Äô stalking her with ‚Äòlong-lens cameras‚Äô. Firstly, zoom is usually not a good thing (see Now‚Äôs ‚ÄòCircle of Shame‚Äô etc‚Ä¶you know‚Ä¶VPLs, sweat patches, cellulite, etc). Secondly, not all paparazzi are old. In fact, some are young and date celebrities (admittedly only sleazy ones like Britney‚Äôs ex Adnan Ghalib‚Ä¶)

Most likely to say: I‚Äôm just a normal lundun gal, honest‚Ä¶ooh but Chanel shoes are amazing!!

In the red corner, LA-LA land fruit-loop Lady GaGa (1)‚Ä¶see also GaGa ‚Äì (2) ‚Äì noun, a liar or an impersonator, i.e.: Lily Allen pulled a GaGa last week‚Ä¶

The obligatory fairytale: There was once a singer who seemed to be the poster girl for post op success. In fact, she was a woman, but besides that she was totally fake, so much so that everything from her long ‚Äòplatinum‚Äô hair (read: ‚Äòperoxide and hair extension partayy‚Äô) to her KKK-at-Christmas costume (see right) may have made people assume she was once Little Mr Riding hood‚Ä¶ Or in a No Doubt tribute band‚Ä¶

Likes to‚Ä¶ : Party, presumably? She went to school with Paris Hilton, which seems to say a lot about this Lady‚Äôs attitude. ‚ÄòJust Dance‚Äô definitely doesn‚Äôt ask to be followed with the words ‚Äòbut it‚Äôs 3am and I‚Äôm too tired!!‚Äô I imagine that she practices her moves whilst doing ordinary stuff like say‚Ä¶walking over men wearing stilletos and busting into random houses (this didn‚Äôt take much of the video to said song to asscertain..)

Most likely to say: ‚ÄúJust Dance‚Äù, ‚ÄúJust Drink‚Ä¶Probably No Rohypnol In There‚Äù, ‚ÄúJust Get In The Kiddies‚Äô Paddling Pool And Ride Shamu With Me‚Äù, ‚ÄúJust Rent Some Friends For The Night‚Äù‚Ä¶

HERE WE GO‚Ä¶

Hannahjdavies.com takes an indepth look at the two high-living ‚Äòheirheads‚Äô‚Ä¶:

It‚Äôs always been okay to have multiple occupations. Unless your name really is Martine McCutcheon, then you can be a singer moonlighting as an actress and vice versa; a reality TV star turned perfumer turned writer; you can even be famous just for the size of your assets, whether they‚Äôre paper, bricks or simply silicone. However, projecting an image of classiness and professional standard is always advised, first and foremost. How can one talk about money in the press let alone brag about a bank balance which makes Miley Cyrus‚Äô paycheque look like child abuse?

The trick is not to go in for all out P-O-S-H, whether you were born so or have recently acquired your squillions (the idea being that one obviously didn‚Äôt go to finishing school in Switzerland if one feels the need to prefix her name with a word with makes the real aristocracy cringe, (right Vickaaaay Beckham?) and if one did, then one obviously didn‚Äôt take much away from their education other than a Blackberry crammed full of viscounts and heiresses Pins‚Ä¶)

Anyhow, I digress. The idea is to hint to a life well lived rather then advertise it, neon sign and all. The Cuban cigars in the ashtray and the red soles of your Louboutins will tell your illustrious story without the ‚Äòumms‚Äô, ‚Äòlikes‚Äô and references to that ‚Äòthing‚Äô you had with Russell Brand.

(Not unless that actually IS the story‚Ä¶take note 2008‚Äôs Georgina Bailie (aka Andrew Sach‚Äôs granddaughter)).

Basically, it‚Äôs all about ‚Äúkeeping it real‚Äù‚Ä¶or giving the illusion that you‚Äôve kept it real. Nouveau riche is a brassy and un-classy look, and, having heaped a title onto herself, I expected so much more from one such madame.

US export Lady GaGa ‚Äì real name Joanne Stefani Germanotta ‚Äì not only went to school with and dresses like Donatella Versace but also sings, quite repetitively, of her obsession with money (see ‚ÄúMoney Honey‚Äù), fame (not just on title track ‚ÄúThe Fame‚Äù), the paparazzi (eponymous ditty ‚ÄúPaparazzi‚Äù says it all), men (‚ÄúBoys, Boys, Boys‚Äù), champagne (name checked a fair few times) and Hollywood (I just couldn‚Äôt listen to anymore of this pretentious twaddle by then, sorry).

Hearing her repeat ‚Äúwe‚Äôre beautiful and dirty rich‚Äù over and over again without a hint of sarcasm or irony or modesty or gratitude is quite depressing, honestly. In times of economic struggle, GaGa‚Äôs material obsession seems to amount to little substance.
